EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - AQUEOUS AMMONIA STORAGE SYSTEM



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



The PSEG Fossil, LLC (PSEG Fossil) - Mercer Generating Station has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes.  PSEG Fossil's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The PSEG Fossil - Mercer Generating Station is located on Lamberton Road in Hamilton Township, Mercer County, New Jersey.  Mercer Generating Station has one regulated toxic substance, aqueous ammonia.  The concentration of ammonia within the solution is between 29.4% and 29.8% by weight.  Aqueous ammonia is utilized as an integral component of the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system on Units No. 1 and 2 to reduce Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) emissions.



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



For Mercer Generating Station, the potential worst-case toxic release scenario involves the entire contents of one aqueous ammonia storage tank.  The Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP*Comp model was used to determine that the distance to toxic endpoint for such a release remains within the property boundary and, therefore, does not affect any public or environmental receptors.  The storage facility is equipped with a secondary containment and an underground concrete vault to contain spills.  The vault is designed to mitigate accidental spills and to provide safety for employees and the community. 



The alternative release scenario analyzed was a break in the transfer hose from a tank truck during the aqueous ammonia unloading.  Also using RMP*Comp, the distance to toxic endpoint remains within the property boundary and, therefore, does not affect any public or envi

ronmental receptors.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The following is a summary of the accident prevention program currently being developed at the facility.  



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



Mercer Generating Station has developed a variety of technical documents that will be used to help maintain safe operation of the aqueous ammonia process.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards, and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations are provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs)(SDSs). 



HAZARD REVIEW



Hazard Reviews are conducted on a periodic basis. The review teams consists of engineering, maintenance, operations, safety, and environmental personnel, as well as a team leader and design engineers provided by contractors.  The process hazard analysis method chosen for evaluating the ammonia system was a HazOp.  During the HazOp analysis, the design intent and conditions for each major piece of equipment were identified.  Guide words and potential deviations were postulated for each system.  Recommendations for improved safety are recorded with a schedule to incorporate the change in the timely fashion.  



Mercer Generating Station has written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures will be periodically reviewed and certified as current and accurate. 



TRAINING



To complement the written procedures for process operations, PSEG Fossil has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employ

ees involved in operating the aqueous ammonia system. All of the training has been documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



MAINTENANCE



PSEG Fossil has developed procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. Maintenance personnel have received training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure they can perform jobs in a safe manner.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment is functioning properly.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



PSEG Fossil has no accidents in the past 5 years.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



PSEG Fossil maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program will be updated when necessary based on modifications made to the processes.  The overall emergency response program for Mercer Generating Station is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



SAFETY



PSEG Fossil strives for continuous improvement in its safety programs.  Including training employees to safely perform assigned tasks and encouraging employees to suggest changes or improvements that will help improve safety and performance.  Preventative maintenance is performed to minimize the potential for unanticipated failure of operating equipment.



PSEG Fossil has reviewed and updated many of the prevention program elements, including written operating procedures, mechanical integrity programs, and the emergency response plan.  Recommendations identified during t

he hazard review of the aqueous ammonia process equipment and procedures have been incorporated.
